School of Physical Science and Technology ShanghaiTech University Shanghai 201210 PR China In this work, we constructed the low Miller index surfaces of (100), (001), (111), and (110) of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst. Through extensive DFT calculations, we found that the oxygen vacancy (VO) formation energies on the (100) and (001) surfaces were <1.0 eV, whereas those on the (111) and (110) surfaces were >3.0 eV. We further examined the dissociation of molecular hydrogen (H2) on these surfaces, and found that H2 homolytic dissociation tended to occur on surfaces with lower VO formation energies, while H2 heterolytic dissociation were favored on those with higher VO formation energies. CO2 adsorption and activation on the different surfaces of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst were investigated, and on surfaces with lower VO formation energies, CO2 adsorbs in a linear configuration (ln-CO2*), while on surfaces with higher VO formation energies, CO2 adopts in a bent adsorption geometry (bt-CO2*) and is easier to dissociate. For HCOO formation from ln-CO2* + H*, the (110) surface has the lowest energy barrier, so it is likely the most active surface for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol (CH3OH). Thus, we compared the CH3OH formation pathway on the ZnGa2O4(110) surface with the pathways for direct and indirect CO2 dissociation, and predicted it to favor CH3OH production. Our calculations reveal the active surfaces of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH, and provide insights into the experimentally observed high CH3OH selectivity, which should be important for the rational design of Zn-based spinel catalysts for this reaction. Graphical abstract Active surfaces of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol are revealed by DFT calculations. Image, graphical abstract Keywords ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst Methanol synthesis CO2 hydrogenation DFT calculations Active surfaces Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to the rapid development of the economy and technology, our dependence on non-renewable fossil resources, such as oil, coal and natural gas, remains very high, which leads to excessive carbon emissions mainly in the form of CO2 and greatly contributes to the greenhouse effect [1]. Currently, the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere greatly exceeds the capacity for the natural carbon cycle of the Earth. As a result, scientists are seeking for effective methods to address the excessive carbon emission and the climate change crisis faced by the humanity, specifically by developing efficient Carbon Capture, Utilization, and Storage (CCUS) [2] technologies. Catalytic technology plays a pivotal role in the modern chemical and energy industries including the area of CO2 utilization. Catalysts are being developed to recycle atmospheric CO2 by utilizing green hydrogen derived from seawater electrolysis for the CO2 hydrogenation process [3]. Through the use of heterogeneous catalysts, CO2 can be efficiently converted into high-value-added chemicals [4]. Currently, CH3OH can serve as a clean fuel to replace or add to diesel and gasoline, while also being a key intermediate for producing organic chemicals. Therefore, catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 into CH3OH has become an effective and viable strategy for achieving "carbon neutrality". Recently, significant progress has been made in developing efficient catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH. Extensive studies were conducted on various heterogeneous catalysts, including noble metal catalysts [5], intermetallic catalysts [6], metal sulfides [7], and metal oxide catalyst [8–10]. Recently, spinel-structured nanocatalysts [11], particularly Zn-based spinel oxide catalysts, such as ZnAlOx [11,12], ZnFeOx [13,14], ZnZrOx [15], and ZnGaOx [16–22], have garnered considerable attention. These catalysts were shown to exhibit high CH3OH selectivity and catalytic stability under relatively high temperature conditions in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, as an important component of bifunctional catalysts, they were shown to allow for high product selectivity for the direct synthesis of olefins [19], aromatics [23], and other chemical fuels [24] from CO2 hydrogenation. Consequently, Zn-based spinel catalysts have become some of the most important metal oxide catalysts for methanol synthesis in the Methanol-to-Olefins (MTO) process [25–27] In 2021, Huš et al. [28] conducted a DFT and microkinetic study to investigate the mechanism of methanol synthesis from syngas (CO + H2) over ZnAl2O4 spinel catalysts. Zhang et al. [29] found that ZnAl2O4 could undergo surface reconstruction during CO2 hydrogenation, resulting in the formation of an amorphous ZnO phase, which was characterized and found to promote the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH reaction. Song et al. [12] studied the role of Cu/ZnAl2O4 spinel in promoting the dissociation of H2, which facilitates CO2 hydrogenation for methanol synthesis. Yang et al. [16] discovered for the first time that ZnFe2O4 spinel oxide exhibits a high CH3OH selectivity of 84.5 % in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, and the product selectivity can be further shifted to C₂+OH with a selectivity of 98.5 % among the oxygenates after innovatively introducing the Fe5C2 phase to form an ZnFe2O4/Fe5C2 interfacial structure. For ZnZrOₓ solid solutions, Lee et al. [15] synthesized Pd/ZnZrOₓ catalysts, and found that the CH3OH selectivity was significantly enhanced when compared to bare ZnZrOx, while maintaining stable operation for over 100 hours. These studies have significantly advanced the potential for using Zn-based spinel catalysts for the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH reaction. As a semiconductor with a relatively high bandgap, the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst is promising for applications in photo-catalysis [30] and electro-catalysis [20]. In 2018, Liu et al. [17] first reported its use in combination with SAPO-34 molecular sieve as a bifunctional catalyst, which exhibited a C₂-C₄ olefin selectivity of 86 % in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction with a CO2 conversion rate of up to 13 %. Notably, the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst demonstrated a CH3OH selectivity of 100 % under reaction conditions of 250 °C–400 °C and a H₂/CO2 ratio of 3:1, and the CO2 conversion rate exceeded 15 % at 400 °C. Furthermore, their Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) characterization showed that oxygen vacancies were readily generated on the catalyst after calcination. In 2020, Liu et al. [18] performed H₂-D₂ exchange characterization, and found ZnGa2O4 to exhibit very strong H2 activation, significantly surpassing in H₂ reactivity of ZnAl2O4, ZnCr2O4 and MgAl2O4. They also confirmed that the −Zn−O− motif played an important role in H₂ activation, and that under the same reaction conditions, ZnGa2O4 showed more pronounced VO signals than ZnAl2O4. Recently, Wang et al. [25] combined Thermal Programmed Desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) and EPR characterizations to show that ZnGa2O4 had a significantly higher activity for CO2 activation than Mg-based and Ni-based spinel catalysts [18,25]. The in situ infrared (IR) revealed clear signals of such intermediate species as HCOO* and CH3O* during the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH reaction, suggesting that they are important intermediates in this reaction. Furthermore, they also proposed a reaction mechanism of CH3OH synthesis using Zn-based spinel catalysts. Although several studies have been conducted on the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH, the detailed active surface structure remains unclear. In this work, after reviewing the existing experimental literature [17–19,25], we constructed low Miller-index surface models of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst, including the (100), (001), (111) and (110) surfaces, and performed extensive DFT calculations. We investigated the hydrogen migration mechanism on the different surfaces of ZnGa2O4 and the adsorption and activation of CO2, and calculated the energy barriers for the formation of the HCOO* intermediate on the different surfaces. And we calculate the CH3OH formation and CO formation pathway for ZnGa2O4(110) surface. Our work provides significant insights into the reaction mechanism of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst in the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH reaction including the active surfaces, thus offering new perspectives for the crystal facet engineering of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst. 2 Computational methods All periodic DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [31,32], employing the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) [33] exchange-correlation functional and the projector-augmented wave (PAW) potentials [34,35]. Additionally, we also compared some of the energetics calculated with the DFT and DFT+U [36,37] approaches using the above functional, and as shown in Table S1, results from the DFT+U calculations are quite close to the DFT results, suggesting our DFT energetics to be reliable. Transition states were located using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) [38,39] method and verified through harmonic frequency analysis. We conducted an energy cutoff test, as shown in Table S2, and selected 450 eV as the energy cutoff, with a Gaussian smearing width of 0.05 eV applied. The electronic energy of the supercell was converged to within 10−4 eV, and the forces on all unconstrained atoms were converged to within 0.03 eV/Å. A (3 × 3 × 1) k-point mesh, generated using a Γ-centered Monkhorst-Pack scheme, was employed for surface optimization [22]. Models of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst surfaces were constructed using Materials Visualizer from Materials Studio [40]. The selection of the unit cell for ZnGa2O4 was based on the work of Aillex et al. [41]. The lattice parameters of the cubic primitive unit cell (PUC) of ZnGa2O4 (c-ZnGa2O4) were determined as a = b = c = 8.33 Å, close to their experimental values of 8,32 Å [42]. Models of four low-index ZnGa2O4 surfaces were built based on Jia's work [22]. The detailed model selection and surface energy calculations are presented in Table S3 and Fig. S1. In our calculations, no surface reconstruction was observed during the optimization of these models with relatively low surface energies. The (100) and (111) surfaces were modeled using a p(2 × 2) supercell with dimensions of a = 11.79 Å, b = 11.97 Å, and c = 19.36 Å for the (100) surface, and a = 11.79 Å, b = 11.97 Å, and c = 24.02 Å for the (111) surface. The (100) surface consisted of 8 Zn, 24 Ga, and 48 O atoms, distributed across three atomic layers, while the (111) surface was comprised of 16 Zn, 32 Ga, and 64 O atoms, distributed across seven atomic layers. The (001) and (110) surfaces were modeled using a p(2 × 1) supercell with dimensions of a = 11.79 Å, b = 11.97 Å, and c = 19.36 Å for the (001) surface, and a = 11.79 Å, b = 11.97 Å, and c = 24.02 Å for the (110) surface. The (001) surface consisted of 8 Zn, 20 Ga, and 40 O atoms, arranged in four atomic layers, while the (110) surface was comprised of 12 Zn, 20 Ga, and 40 O atoms, arranged in five atomic layers. The formation energy of VO with respect to gas phase O2 is defined as the reaction energy of the thermal desorption of molecular O2: Δ E f , O V , O 2 = E V O − surface − E Perfect + 1 2 E O 2 Moreover, the formation energy of a VO site ( Δ E f , V O , H 2 / H 2 O ) with respect to gas phase H2/H2O is defined as: Δ E f , O V , H 2 / H 2 O = E V O − surface − E Perfect − E H 2 + E H 2 O In the above equations, EVo-surface, EPerfect, EO2, EH2 and EH2O denote the total energies of the defective surface, perfect surface, and gas phase O2, H2 and H2O. The adsorption energy of an adsorbate A on the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst surface is defined as: E ads , A = E total − ( E surface + E A ) where Etotal, Esurface, and EA are the total energies of the surface with the adsorbate, the clean slab, and the adsorbate as a free molecule, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 VO formation energies on different ZnGa2O4 surfaces Characterization of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalysts revealed the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies after calcination [17]. In this study, we first calculated the VO formation energies for the ZnGa2O4 (100), (001), (111) and (110) surfaces. As shown in Fig. 1a , the ZnGa2O4 (100) surface has a symmetric structure, so formation of VO sites (labeled O1 to O8) on one side of the slab is considered. The VO formation energies ( Δ E f , O V ) for O1, O3, O5, and O7 are −0.35 eV, while those for O2, O4, O6, and O8 are 0.04 eV. We note that the Zn sites exposed on the (100) surface are actually located in the subsurface layer, which bind the surrounding O atoms to form a four-coordinated Zn-O bond structure with an average Zn-O bond length of 2.10 Å. Ga atoms bind both surface and subsurface O atoms to form a five-coordinated Ga-O bond structure with an average Ga-O bond length of 1.97 Å. This surface is thermodynamically more prone to the direct formation of oxygen vacancies by removing oxygen atoms. As shown in Fig. 1b, the ZnGa2O4 (001) surface consists of 2 Zn atoms, 4 Ga atoms, and 8 O atoms, where the Zn atoms bind subsurface O atoms to form a four-coordinated Zn-O bond structure with an average Zn-O bond length of 1.97 Å. The Ga atoms bind five surrounding O atoms to form a five-coordinated Ga-O bond structure with an average Ga-O bond length of 1.99 Å. Due to the symmetry of the surface, we only label the four O atoms on the opposite surface as O1 to O4. The four VO sites can be categorized into two types: the Δ E f , O V values of O1 and O3 are −0.71 eV, while those of O2 and O4 are 0.16 eV. This suggests that the (001) surface has a relatively high tendency to form oxygen vacancies. Fig. 1c shows the ZnGa2O4 (111) surface, which has a six-membered ring structure. Due to the symmetry of the surface, we only studied the seven surface oxygen atoms. The Δ E f , O V value for OV 1 is 2.14 eV, while those for OV 2 to OV 8 are 3.08 eV. On this surface, Zn atoms bind surrounding O atoms to form a three-coordinated Zn-O structure, thus exhibiting unsaturation in coordination. Ga atoms exposed on this surface also form a three-coordinated Ga-O structure, which are similarly unsaturated sites. The ZnGa2O4 (110) surface exhibits a mirror symmetry. The eight O atoms exposed on the surface have the same coordination environment, each forming two Ga-O bonds and two Zn-O bonds. The Δ E f , O V value for this surface is 3.76 eV for oxygen sites. The Zn sites bind O atoms to form a three-coordinated Zn-O structure, while the Ga atoms bind surrounding O atoms to form a four-coordinated Ga-O structure. As lower VO formation energies lead to easier formation of oxygen vacancies during direct thermal treatment in experiments, the tendency of VO formation on the different surfaces follows the order of (100) > (001) > (111) > (110) from our calculated VO formation energies. 3.2 Dissociative adsorption of H2 on different ZnGa2O4 surfaces The ability of H₂ dissociative adsorption on the catalyst surface is often used as a measure of the activity of the catalyst for H₂ activation, and for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, H2-D2 exchange experiments are commonly used find out the reactivity of the catalyst for H2 activation [17,18]. H2 activation can be categorized into heterolytic and homolytic dissociations. H2 heterolytic dissociation results in the formation of two oppositely charged H atoms, [43] where the negatively charged H atom binds the Ga or Zn atom to form a hydride, and the positively charged H atom attaches to the O atom as a proton. On the other hand, H₂ homolytic dissociation produces two negatively charged H atoms both binding the O atoms [44]. Based on previous studies, we select VO sites with higher VO formation energies on the various surfaces of ZnGa2O4 as the potential active sites for the catalyst [43]. From the VO sites on the ZnGa2O4 (100), (001), (111) and (110) surfaces shown in Fig. 1 and their VO formation energies listed in Table S4, the following VO sites we selected as the potential active sites: OV6 on the (100) surface, OV2 on the (001) surface, OV2 on the (111) surface, and OV 2 on the (110) surface (Fig. S2). Fig. 2a presents the potential energy profiles for the formation of oxygen vacancies via H2 reduction to form the OV 6 site on the ZnGa2O4 (100) surface and the OV 2 site on the (001) surface, and Fig. S3 display the adsorption structures for H2 dissociation and H2O formation on the perfect ZnGa2O4 (001) and (100) surfaces. Although Ga atoms are exposed on both the ZnGa2O4 (100) and (001) surfaces, the computational results indicate that H2 dissociation proceeds via homolytic cleavage of the HH bond, where the resulting two hydrogen atoms are directly adsorbed onto the two oxygen sites on the surface with adsorption energies (Eads_2H) of −4.38 eV on the (001) surface and −4.98 eV on the (100) surface, suggesting that this process is thermodynamically favorable. For the (001) surface, H2 dissociation into two hydrogen atoms occurs without an energy barrier, and that on the (100) surface requires a low energy barrier of ETS1 = 0.15 eV, indicating that H2 dissociation is also kinetically favorable on these two surfaces. The further migration of the hydrogen from the O3 site to the O2 site on the (001) surface results in the formation of an adsorbed H2O molecule with a much higher energy barrier Ea,TS2 of 1.04 eV. Figs. 2b and 3a present the potential energy profiles for H2 dissociation on the ZnGa2O4 (111) and (110) surfaces. Unlike the (001) and (100) surfaces, where H2 dissociation is always homolytic, heterolytic dissociation of H2 can also occur on the (111) surface. Fig. 2b illustrates the potential energy barrier for H₂ dissociation on the (111) surface with the related structures shown in Fig. S4. Upon H2 dissociation, one hydrogen atom is adsorbed at the O2 site, while the other hydrogen is adsorbed onto the Zn2 or Ga2 sites, resulting in heterolytic dissociation. Notably, the dissociative adsorption of H2 into two hydrogen atoms at the Ga2 and O2 sites is exothermic with an adsorption energy (Eads_2H) of −1.87 eV, with the Ga-H and OH bond lengths of 1.53 Å and 1.02 Å, respectively. In contrast, the dissociative adsorption into two hydrogen atoms at the Zn2 and O2 sites is endothermic by 0.11 eV, making it thermodynamically unfavorable. Furthermore, the energy barriers for heterolytic dissociation of 0.29 and 0.03 eV are lower than that for homolytic dissociation of 0.81 eV, indicating that the heterolytic dissociation of H2 on the ZnGa2O4 (111) surface is more favorable. We further investigated the migration of hydrogen from Ga-Ha, Zn-Ha, and OHa to the adjacent hydroxyl group (O2 Hb), leading to the formation of an adsorbed H2O molecule. Due to the unsaturated coordination of the Ga atoms on the ZnGa2O4(111) surface, we found the hydrogen adsorbed at the Zn or O site to be influenced by the unsaturated Ga atom during the migration to form H2O. Consequently, we did not calculate the transition state for the migration of the hydrogen adsorbed at the Zn or O site, but focused on the transfer of Ga-Ha to O2 Hb, leading to VO formation. Migration of Ga-H to form H₂O involves an energy barrier of 1.78 eV with an H2O desorption energy of 0.91 eV, suggesting that the reduction of the ZnGa2O4(111) surface by H2 to form the VO and the H₂O molecule is thermodynamically unfavorable. Fig. 3a illustrates the potential energy surface for the dissociation of H2 and VO formation on the ZnGa2O4 (110) surface, and the adsorption structures are shown in Fig S5. Notably, the formation of hydrides at the metal sites (Ga2, Zn2) is thermodynamically more favorable than the formation of protons at the adjacent oxygen atoms. For the transition state for the dissociation of H2 onto two O atoms of surfaces, the two hydrogen atoms formed from the cleavage of the HH bond in H2 tend to adsorb more strongly onto the adjacent Ga atoms. Subsequently, the hydrogen atoms migrate from the Ga atom to the O atom, which prevents the identification of a distinct transition state. As a result, homolytic dissociation of H2 does not occur on this surface. At the Zn site, the dissociation of H2 incurs an energy barrier of 0.15 eV, which is slightly lower than the energy barrier required for dissociation at the Ga site. From our calculations, the hydroxyl group is strongly attracted to the surrounding Zn atoms, making it impossible to locate the transition state TS2. Hence, it is difficult for the H atoms adsorbed on the Zn atoms to migrate to the surrounding hydroxyl group to form H2O molecules. The transfer of Ha from the Ga atom to the O2 site involves an energy barrier of 0.96 eV. In addition, the desorption energy of H2O on this surface is 0.19 eV. and compared to the (111) surface, the (110) surface is thermodynamically favorable, leading to VO formation on this surface. Interestingly, H2 cannot undergo heterolytic dissociation on the (100) and (001) surfaces, although it can occur on the (111) and (100) surfaces. Thus, we attempt to correlate the VO formation energy with the adsorption energy of two hydrogen atoms for the different surfaces as shown in Fig. 3b To our surprise, we found that the surfaces with lower VO formation energy, such as (100) and (001), exhibited a more negative adsorption energy of two hydrogen atoms at the two surface oxygen sites with Eads,2H-(100) = −4.97 eV and Eads,2H-(001) = −4.37 eV, suggesting that the formation of a structure with two hydrogen atoms adsorbed at two oxygen sites are thermodynamically strongly favorable. This is consistent with the fact that in our calculations for the (001) and (100) surfaces, the initial Ga-H adsorption structure is optimized to a structure with the H atoms migrated to the oxygen sites to form the hydroxyl group. 3.3 CO2 activation and HCOO* formation on defective ZnGa2O4 surfaces The ability of metal oxide catalyst to activate CO2 is key to the activity of the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, regardless of whether the product is CH3OH or CO [10,45,46]. Results from CO2-TPD and in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterizations reveal that the amount of oxygen vacancies on the ZnGa2O4 catalyst significantly decreases from 31 % to 20 % after CO2 adsorption [18]. 3.3.1 Adsorption of CO2 on ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst The adsorption configurations of CO2 on the defect surfaces can be categorized into linear CO2 (ln-CO2*), bent CO₂ (bt-CO2*), and carbonate (carb-CO2*) [10]. Our calculations show that on the oxygen defect surfaces of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst, CO2 adsorbs in the ln-CO2* configuration on both the (001) and (100) surfaces as shown in Fig. S6. For the (001) surface, the average CO bond length in the adsorbed CO2 is 1.18 Å and the bond angle is 177.2°, which are close to those of the gas phase CO2 molecule. The distances between Ob and Ga2 and Ga3 atoms are 2.98 Å and 3.14 Å, respectively, indicating that CO2 is weakly physisorbed at the OV 2 site on the (001) surface. For the (100) surface, the average CO bond length in the adsorbed CO2 is 1.18 Å, and the distances between Ob and the Ga2 and Ga3 atoms are 3.22 Å and 3.21 Å, respectively, so CO2 adsorption on the (100) surface is also characterized by weak ln-CO2* adsorption. In contrast, on both the ZnGa2O4 (111) and (110) surfaces, the CO2 adsorbs in the bt-CO2* configuration. For the (111) surface, one oxygen atom (Ob) of CO2 is adsorbed at the OV 2 site to form Ga-O and Zn-O bonds with the adjacent Ga₂ and Zn2 atoms, respectively, and the carbon atom forms a Zn-C bond with Zn2 with a bond length of 1.99 Å. The adsorption energy of the bt-CO2* on the (111) surface is 0.49 eV, and the endothermicity is likely due to the formation of the Zn-C bond. The bt-CO2* configuration features CO bond lengths of 1.29 Å and 1.32 Å with an OC—O bond angle of 113.9° In the bt-CO2* adsorption configuration on the (111) surface, as shown in Fig. S6, one of the oxygen atoms in CO2 is adsorbed at the VO site on the surface, while the carbon atom forms a Ga-C bond with the Ga atom with a bond length of 2.02 Å. The CO bond lengths in the adsorbed CO2 are 1.21 Å and 1.38 Å, respectively. The adsorption energy of CO2 on the (110) surface is −0.33 eV, and the exothermicity indicates CO2 adsorption is thermodynamically favorable on this surface. 3.3.2 Direct dissociation of CO2 on different ZnGa2O4 surfaces Experimentally, CO₂-TPD and EPR are typically combined to analyze the changes in the VO signal on the catalyst after exposure to CO2 [18], which allow for the qualitative evaluation of the capacity for the catalyst to adsorb CO2. CO2 adsorbed at the surface VO sites may undergo direct dissociation, and the VO sites facilitate the cleavage of the C–O bond in CO2, leading to the formation of CO* and O* species [45]. The ability of the catalyst to promote the direct dissociation of CO2 plays a critical role in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Fig. 4 illustrates the potential energy surface for the direct dissociation of CO₂ on the different surfaces of ZnGa2O4, CO adsorption energies on the different surfaces are presented in Table S6. Our calculations show that the (111) surface exhibits the lowest energy barrier of 0.06 eV for CO2 dissociation, and in its transition state, one oxygen atom (Ob) occupies the OV 2 site, while the other oxygen atom (Oa) binds the C atom to form the adsorbed CO. The C–Ob and C–Oa bond lengths are 1.93 Å and 1.19 Å, respectively, confirming the reduction of CO2 to CO. Moreover, a Zn–C bond between the adsorbed CO and the Zn₂ site has a length of 2.14 Å. For the ZnGa2O4 (110) surface, CO2 direct dissociation incurs an energy barrier of 0.74 eV, while those for the (001) and (100) surfaces are significantly higher at 3.96 eV and 4.36 eV, respectively. Thus, the tendency of CO2 direct dissociation on the different surfaces of ZnGa2O4 follows the order of (111) > (110) > (001) > (100). Notably, the particularly high energy barriers for CO2 direct dissociation on the (001) and (100) surfaces suggest that CO2 is less likely to undergo direct dissociation on these surfaces. We conjecture that the tendency of CO2 direct dissociation may be closely related to the adsorption configuration of CO2 on the surface. Specifically, the direct dissociation of ln-CO2* to form CO* and O* is more challenging than that of bt-CO2*, and the adsorption configuration of CO2 is likely influenced by the surface structure of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst. We hypothesize that the VO formation energy on the different surfaces plays a crucial role in determining the CO2 adsorption configuration, as surfaces with lower VO formation energies tend to favor the ln-CO2* adsorption structure, while those with higher VO formation energies prefer the bt-CO2* adsorption configuration. The high endothermicity in the direct dissociation of the ln-CO2* on the (001) and (100) surfaces results in their higher dissociation barriers. 3.3.3 HCOO* formation on different ZnGa2O4 surfaces Experimentally, in situ FTIR characterization has directly confirmed HCOO* as an important intermediate species in the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH reaction [13,25]. Thus, if a catalyst facilitates the ready formation of the HCOO* intermediate, it may process strong catalytic activity for the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH reaction [37]. In our previous studies, we found that the ln-CO2* tends to react with the surface H* to form the HCOO* [10]. Here, we consider the physisorbed ln-CO2* at the VO sites on the ZnGa2O4 (100), (001), (111) and (110) surfaces as the initial structure as shown in Figs. S8 and S9), which is hydrogenated to form the HCOO* by the H atom formed after H2 dissociation. The potential energy profiles for the ln-CO2* + H* → HCOO* reaction on the different ZnGa2O4 surfaces are shown in Fig. 5 . Surfaces with lower VO formation energies, namely the (001) and (100) surfaces, are thermodynamically more favorable for H* adsorption at the oxygen sites, consistent with previous studies [37,47,48]. The relative energies of ln-CO2* + H* on the ZnGa2O4 (100) and (001) surfaces, compared to their defective surfaces, are −0.84 eV and −1.51 eV, respectively. Meanwhile, the relative energies of HCOO* on the (100) and (001) surfaces, compared to In-CO2* + H*, are 0.78 eV and 1.07 eV. These energy trends differ from those observed on the surfaces of other metal oxide catalysts, such as In2O3 and Cu/ZnO, where the energy trends are distinct [37,47] Furthermore, the energy barriers of HCOO* formation on the (100) and (001) surfaces are 3.09 eV and 2.20 eV, respectively. Thus, HCOO* formation is thermodynamically and kinetically unfavorable on the (001) and (100) surfaces. For the (111) and (110) surfaces, after H2 dissociation, the H atom is more likely to adsorb at the metal atoms, such as Zn and Ga, and the co-adsorption energies for ln-CO2* + H_M* (M = Zn, Ga) are 0.25 eV and −0.36 eV, respectively, whereas the adsorption energies for the HCOO* on these two surfaces are −0.82 eV and −1.66 eV, respectively. Furthermore, the energy barriers of HCOO* formation are 0.40 eV and 0.26 eV, respectively, so HCOO* formation is thermodynamically and kinetically favorable on both the (111) and (110) surfaces. 3.4 Mechanism of methanol formation on the ZnGa2O4 catalyst It is well-established that the CO2 hydrogenation reactions typically occur at the VO sites on the metal oxide catalysts, such as In2O3 [10,49], ZnO [50] and ZnFe2O4 spinel catalyst [13]. In previous work of Liu et al. [17], VO was proposed to act as the active sites for CO2 hydrogenation on the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst. In earlier sections, we discussed the mechanisms of VO formation across different surfaces of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst and identified the ZnGa2O4(110) surface as the most promising candidate for catalyzing CO2 hydrogenation. Therefore, here we focus on the formation mechanisms of CH3OH and CO on the ZnGa2O4(110) surface. Fig. 6 . presents the potential energy profiles for the formations of CH3OH and CO, where the black line corresponds to the pathway for CH3OH formation via ln-CO2*, while the blue line represents the indirect dissociation of bt-CO2*, and the pink line represents the bt-CO2* direct dissociation on the VO-ZnGa2O4(110) surface. For the CH3OH formation pathway (the structure as shown in Fig. S10), ln-CO2* is adsorbed on the Ga2 site and hydrogenated by H* via TS1 (Ea = 0.26 eV) to form HCOO*. HCOO* then undergoes further hydrogenation by H* at the Ga2 site via TS2, resulting in the H2COO structure with a very low energy barrier of 0.20 eV. Then, H2COO* dissociates to fill the VO , leading to the adsorbed H2CO via TS3 (Ea = 0.48 eV). H2CO* is further hydrogenated by an H adsorbed at the Ga2 site, producing the methoxy CH3O* intermediate, which is an exothermic step. CH3O* is then protonated by a proton located at the O6 site via TS4 (Ea = 0.27 eV) to form the adsorbed CH3OH, desorption of which leads to the regeneration of the perfect ZnGa2O4(110) surface. Thus, from the calculated energy barriers, the rate-determining step for CH3OH formation is the dissociation of H2COO to form H2CO with an energy barrier of 0.48 eV. Among the surface intermediates, HCOO* and CH3O* are stable along the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH pathway, consistent with results from previous IR experiments [17,25]. We provide additional computational results in Fig. S12 and Table S7 to show that the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst is more favorable for the formation of CH3OH over formic acid in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, we also included Gibbs free energy corrections to the stationary states along the CH3OH and CO pathways in Tables S8–S10 and Fig. S13. At 523 K, the highest energy barrier of CH3OH formation remains lower than that of CO formation, so the calculated Gibbs free energy barriers are also consistent with the 100 % CH3OH selectivity observed for the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst at 523 K. For CO formation (The adsorption structures were shown in Fig. S11), TS5 corresponds to the direct dissociation of CO2 to form CO, and TS6 corresponds to the hydrogenation of bt-CO2* to form COOH*, with energy barriers of 0.78 eV and 1.18 eV, respectively. Thus, these energy barriers for the CO formation pathways are much higher than those for the CH3OH formation pathway. Therefore, we conclude that the formation of CH3OH at the VO sites on the ZnGa2O4(110) surface is kinetically more favorable, consistent with the experimentally observed high CH3OH selectivity with the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst. 3.5 Discussion The ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst has been previously demonstrated to have exceptionally high performance in the CO2 hydrogenation for CH3OH reaction [16–18,20,25], although there remain a lack of theoretical understanding on the detailed mechanism. In this work, we employed four different surfaces, namely (100), (001), (111) and (110) as the potential models of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst based on the previous characterization of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst [17,18,25]. As shown in Fig. 7 , we performed extensive DFT calculations to investigate the tendency of the different surfaces to form oxygen vacancies, as well as the activity of H2 dissociation, CO2 adsorption and activation, and the formation of the HCOO* intermediate. The VO formation energies can be used to rationalize the experimental observation for the formation of a large number of oxygen vacancies after calcination of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst [17]. The tendency of VO formation on different surfaces of ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst follows the order of (100) > (001) > (111) > (110). The VO formation energy is widely believed to play a key role in the activation of such absorbed species as H2 and CO2 [51–53] For H2 dissociation on the different surfaces of ZnGa2O4 , we found that the surfaces with lower VO formation energies, namely (100) and (001), could only facilitate homolytic dissociation of H2, whereas both heterolytic and homolytic dissociations are both possible for surfaces with higher VO formation energies, such as the (111) and (110) surfaces. Notably, the tendency for the heterolytic dissociation of H2 in the (111) and (110) surfaces are significantly more pronounced. From H2-D2 exchange experiments, the Zn-based spinel catalyst shows higher activity for H2 activation than the Mg-based spinel catalyst, indicating that the -Zn-O- domain in the spinel oxide plays a vital role in H2 activation [18]. Our calculations on the heterolytic and homolytic dissociations of H2 across the different surfaces of ZnGa2O4 confirm that heterolytic dissociation of H2 on the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst is more favorable for the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH reaction. The mechanism of VO formation involves H2 dissociation and H2O formation and subsequent desorption, and our calculations show that H2O desorption and VO formation on the different ZnGa2O4 surfaces arethermodynamically favorable, consistent with previous experimental observations that the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst exhibits strong activity for H2 activation [17,18,25]. Thus, our study provides valuable insights into the available experimental evidence, and we suggest that an appropriate H2 atmosphere can facilitate the formation of more oxygen vacancies on the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst. For the relationship between the VO formation energies of the ZnGa2O4 different surfaces and their catalytic activities, we made a connection between the adsorption energy of two hydrogen atoms at the different sites and the VO formation energy, suggesting the important influence of the VO formation energy on the adsorption sites of the two hydrogen atoms. Furthermore, the VO formation energy also plays a key role in determining whether H2 dissociation occurs via the heterolytic or homolytic pathway. For CO2 adsorption and direct dissociation on the different surfaces of ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst, our calculations show that on the (100) and (001) surfaces, CO2 adsorbs in the form of ln-CO2*, whose direct dissociation is kinetically unfavorable. In contrast, for the (111) and (110) surfaces, CO2 adsorbs as bt-CO2*, whose direct dissociation exhibits a relatively low energy barrier, thus making the CO2 direct dissociation favorable on these surfaces. Previous experimental observations suggest that HCOO* is a crucial intermediate in the CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH reaction [25], and we evaluate the energy barriers for the formation of HCOO to assess the reactivity of ZnGa2O4 different surfaces. Our calculations indicate that the activity of HCOO* formation follows the order of (110) > (111) > (001) > (100), suggesting that the (110) surface is the most favorable for HCOO* formation and potentially also for CH3OH formation. Additionally, on the (001) and (100) surfaces, the H* can only adsorb at oxygen site. In previous study show that the hydrogen atom in the hydroxyl structure carries a positive charge, while the carbon atom of CO2 also carries a positive charge, resulting in repulsive interactions between the two positively charged species [49], which helps rationalize the unfavorable formation of the HCOO* from the ln-CO2* + H* co-adsorption structure on these surfaces. Moreover, our calculations suggest that surfaces with higher VO formation energies are more conducive to the formation of the HCOO* during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, we deduce that the ZnGa2O4(110) surface is the most active surface for the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH. And we compared the reaction pathways for CH3OH and CO formations, and found that for CH3OH formation to have a lower energy barrier. We performed further Gibbs free energy corrections to the DFT energies, as shown in Fig. S13 and Tables S8–S10. These data show that at 523 K, the highest energy barrier for CH3OH formation is still lower than that for CO formation. This is consistent with previous experimental reports that the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst exhibits high CH3OH selectivity at 523 K [17,18,25]. Future microkinetic analysis will further bridge the gap between experiment and theory, allowing for a deeper understanding of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst [54]. Although our DFT study has rationalized some previous experimental observations on the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst, there remain some unresolved issues for future research. Zhang et al. [29] recently observed surface reconstruction of the ZnAl2O4 catalyst under working conditions leading to the formation of some new phases. Thus, it is conceivable that the ZnGa2O4 catalyst may also be subject to surface reconstruction especially when exposed to varying temperatures, pressures and reactive environments. For instance, the surface may undergo hydroxylation, and a new phase may form on the catalyst surface under suitable conditions, elucidation of which remains a significant challenge to experimental characterization. Theoretically, it is crucial to develop multi-scale simulation methods to address these problems for the Zn-based spinel catalysts. Such studies will not only offer a better understanding on the surface reconstruction of the catalyst under reaction conditions, but also may guide the rational design of more efficient catalysts. 4 Conclusions DFT calculations were carried out to investigate the VO formation energy on the different ZnGa2O4 surfaces, and the VO formation energies on the (100) and (001) surfaces were predicted to be considerably lower than those on the (111) and (110) surfaces. For H₂ dissociation on these surfaces, surfaces with lower VO formation energies were found to favor homolytic activation, whereas surfaces with higher VO energies preferred heterolytic dissociation. For CO2 adsorption and activation, CO2 adsorbs exclusively as an ln-CO₂* on the lower VO formation energy surfaces, while it adsorbs in the bt-CO2*on the higher VO formation energy surfaces, resulting in lower energy barriers for CO2 dissociation. For HCOO* formation, the ZnGa2O4 (110) surface was predicted to have a lower energy barrier, which may serve as the most active surface of this catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH. To explain the high CH3OH selectivity of the ZnGa2O4 catalyst of the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, we further predicted the pathways of CH3OH and CO formations on the ZnGa2O4 (110) surface. Our calculations show that the CH3OH pathway has a lower energy barrier, which aligns well with previous experimental findings for this catalyst. This is thus the first study to theoretically identify the active surfaces of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst, and we also elucidate its catalytic mechanisms for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. These insights are crucial for the rational design of Zn-based spinel catalysts for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: In this work, we constructed the low Miller index surfaces of (100), (001), (111), and (110) of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst. Through extensive DFT calculations, we found that the oxygen vacancy (VO) formation energies on the (100) and (001) surfaces were <1.0 eV, whereas those on the (111) and (110) surfaces were >3.0 eV. We further examined the dissociation of molecular hydrogen (H2) on these surfaces, and found that H2 homolytic dissociation tended to occur on surfaces with lower VO formation energies, while H2 heterolytic dissociation were favored on those with higher VO formation energies. CO2 adsorption and activation on the different surfaces of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst were investigated, and on surfaces with lower VO formation energies, CO2 adsorbs in a linear configuration (ln-CO2*), while on surfaces with higher VO formation energies, CO2 adopts in a bent adsorption geometry (bt-CO2*) and is easier to dissociate. For HCOO formation from ln-CO2* + H*, the (110) surface has the lowest energy barrier, so it is likely the most active surface for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol (CH3OH). Thus, we compared the CH3OH formation pathway on the ZnGa2O4(110) surface with the pathways for direct and indirect CO2 dissociation, and predicted it to favor CH3OH production. Our calculations reveal the active surfaces of the ZnGa2O4 spinel catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH, and provide insights into the experimentally observed high CH3OH selectivity, which should be important for the rational design of Zn-based spinel catalysts for this reaction.
